intro: Galium taygeteum var. violaceum, commonly known as the purple-stemmed bedstraw, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the mountainous regions of southern Europe. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its slender, creeping stems that often have a distinctive purple hue. The plant produces small, white to pale pink flowers arranged in clusters, typically blooming in late spring to early summer. Its leaves are opposite, ovate, and have a slightly hairy texture, contributing to its ornamental appeal. It thrives in moist, shaded environments and is often found in woodland areas or along stream banks.
